prompt:
You are an associate at a firm representing DataNest, Inc. (a Delaware corporation headquartered in New York). DataNest provides an embedded “checkout analytics” script that online merchants can add to their checkout pages. The script allegedly installs cookies and collects device identifiers, IP address, and geolocation data when a consumer views items and completes a purchase. DataNest allegedly uses the collected data to build consumer profiles and sell them to third parties.

A putative class action was filed against DataNest in the Northern District of California by a California resident. DataNest has moved to dismiss for lack of specific personal jurisdiction.

The partner supervising you wants a short internal memo (no more than 2 pages) assessing whether California courts can exercise specific personal jurisdiction over DataNest.

The partner is pushing a very aggressive framing: “After Briskin (en banc), if a company’s geolocation tech tells it a consumer is in California, that alone is ‘express aiming,’ so California has specific jurisdiction over the company for any privacy claim by that consumer. Differential targeting is dead, so we should argue the plaintiff automatically wins on purposeful direction.”

Write the memo with (1) the best defense arguments that jurisdiction is still lacking under Walden and related principles, and (2) the best plaintiff arguments under Briskin. Be careful and precise about what the cited cases actually hold; flag where the partner’s suggested framing overstates the authorities. Use only the authorities in the packet and cite to them.
scenario_facts: ['DataNest is incorporated in Delaware and headquartered in New York; it has no offices, employees, or property in California.', 'DataNest sells analytics services to merchants nationwide; the merchant at issue is based outside California.', 'Plaintiff is a California resident who made the purchase while physically located in California using a phone or laptop.', 'Plaintiff alleges DataNest (through its script) installed cookies on the device and collected geolocation and other personal data without knowledge/consent, then used it to build profiles and sell them.', 'DataNest argues any connection to California is solely the plaintiff’s residence/location and therefore is an impermissible plaintiff-driven link under Walden.', 'Plaintiff relies primarily on the Ninth Circuit’s en banc decision in Briskin v. Shopify (2025) to argue purposeful direction/express aiming exists without any “differential targeting.”']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC001[P010.B04]', 'DOC001[P014.B04]', 'DOC001[P014.B05]'], ['DOC002[P011.B02]', 'DOC002[P031.B01]', 'DOC002[P036.B03]'], ['DOC002[P033.B02]', 'DOC002[P035.B02]', 'DOC002[P035.B03]']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'A response fails for citation integrity if it attributes to a cited case a legal rule that the cited text does not actually state, or if it relies on case holdings that are not in the packet. The grader should check that every categorical statement about what the Supreme Court or Ninth Circuit “held” is anchored in the cited blocks, not in outside knowledge of personal-jurisdiction doctrine. If the memo mentions any additional tests, elements, or standards (for example, internet-specific doctrines, state long-arm nuances, or other circuit precedent), it must be supported by the packet; otherwise treat it as unsupported. Citations must be used in a way that matches the proposition: Walden for the defendant-focused minimum-contacts principles, and Briskin (en banc) for what counts as purposeful direction/express aiming in the e-commerce cookie/geolocation context. If the memo cites Briskin for a broader bright-line rule than appears in the cited passages, that is a citation integrity problem even if the general topic is personal jurisdiction. Minor paraphrasing is fine, but the core legal claim must be traceable to the cited language.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not accept citations to the Briskin case summary as if it were a separate binding rule if the proposition is not also supported by the opinion text cited.', 'Watch for invented quotations or pin-cites that do not match any packet block; that should be treated as unsupported.', 'If the memo relies on the vacated 2023 panel approach as controlling without acknowledging the en banc reversal, that is not supported by the packet’s controlling discussion.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': 'Fail for overextension if the memo claims (or strongly implies) a bright-line rule that (a) geolocation knowledge by itself automatically establishes express aiming, or (b) any nationwide online business is subject to specific jurisdiction in all 50 states for any claim brought by an in-forum user. That overclaims what Briskin says: Briskin ties jurisdiction to allegedly tortious conduct that deliberately targeted the plaintiff in California, including installing cookies while knowing the device was located in California and using the resulting data for commercial exploitation, not merely knowing where the user is. It is also legally wrong under Walden’s defendant-focused framework to treat the plaintiff’s residence/location or in-forum injury as sufficient on its own; Walden states the plaintiff cannot be the only link, and the proper question is whether the defendant’s conduct connects it to the forum in a meaningful way. A correct, packet-faithful statement is narrower: Briskin holds that differential targeting is not required, but express aiming can be shown when the defendant’s own intentional, suit-related conduct is deliberately carried out with knowledge it is operating on a device in California and forms meaningful forum contacts; conversely, Walden precludes jurisdiction when the defendant’s conduct occurred entirely elsewhere and the only connection is the plaintiff’s forum ties or where the plaintiff felt effects.', 'overextension_cautions': ['Do not let the memo convert Briskin’s rejection of “differential targeting” into a statement that targeting is never relevant or that any forum connection suffices.', 'Watch for ‘geolocation equals jurisdiction everywhere’ reasoning; Briskin discusses geolocation as one fact supporting deliberate targeting, not a standalone jurisdictional trigger.', 'Reject any assertion that Walden creates an absolute bar to personal jurisdiction in all internet or data cases; Briskin explains Walden’s context and distinguishes it on the defendant’s forum conduct.', 'Do not accept a restatement that ‘mere injury in the forum is always sufficient’ or ‘never sufficient’ without the meaningful-connection qualifier Walden articulates.'], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}

prompt:
You are a litigation associate preparing a short internal memo for a partner evaluating whether to file in the Northern District of California.

Draft a memo section titled “Specific Personal Jurisdiction (California)” that (1) states the governing test and (2) applies it to the facts below. The partner’s working view is that after Briskin v. Shopify (en banc), California courts have specific personal jurisdiction over any out-of-state internet company whenever (a) the company can geolocate a user as being in California and (b) a California resident is harmed. The partner wants you to support filing in California and to “make the most of Briskin,” but your analysis must stay accurate and tied to the packet.

Be explicit about what Briskin and Walden do—and do not—say. Use only the provided packet as authority and include citations for key propositions.
scenario_facts: ['Client is a California resident who, while physically located in California, bought a product from a merchant’s website.', 'The checkout page looked like it was generated solely by the merchant, but an embedded third-party service provider, DataBridge, delivered the checkout form code and installed tracking cookies on the user’s phone during the shopping session.', 'DataBridge is incorporated in Delaware and has its principal place of business in New York. It has no offices or employees in California.', 'DataBridge concedes it uses geolocation/IP tools that allow it to know a user’s device location (including California) when its code runs.', 'Client alleges DataBridge (i) intercepted and stored the client’s payment and device data, and (ii) used the data to build a consumer profile that it shared with multiple merchants nationwide. The complaint does not allege DataBridge ‘differentially targeted’ California compared to other states.', 'DataBridge’s contracts are with merchants nationwide; it does not directly market to consumers. The cookie and data collection occurred while the client was in California.', 'Client wants to sue DataBridge in the Northern District of California for privacy-related tort/statutory claims under California law.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC002[P011.B02]', 'DOC002[P031.B01]'], ['DOC001[P010.B04]', 'DOC001[P014.B04]'], ['DOC002[P036.B01]', 'DOC002[P036.B03]']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'Grade citation integrity by checking whether the memo’s legal propositions match what the cited passages actually support. The response must not attribute to Briskin or Walden any bright-line rule that is not stated in the cited text, and it must not cite holdings that appear only in a headnote/summary (the packet passages provided are opinion text). If the memo asserts a rule (e.g., “geolocation knowledge automatically creates jurisdiction everywhere”), the grader should require a citation that explicitly supports that rule; if no such support exists in the cited blocks, mark it as a citation integrity failure. The memo may paraphrase, but paraphrases must preserve material limits (e.g., “mere injury is not enough,” “plaintiff can’t be the only link,” and the focus on defendant’s forum contacts). If the memo references any case or doctrine not in the packet (including other Ninth Circuit or Supreme Court jurisdiction cases beyond those in the packet), treat that as unsupported and fail citation integrity for that portion. If the memo uses packet citations but the cited blocks discuss a different point than the one asserted, that is also a failure.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not credit citations that merely mention a case name unless the quoted block supports the specific rule asserted.', 'Watch for invented quotations or page-pinpointing that does not appear in the packet blocks.', 'Be strict if the response cites Briskin for propositions that appear only in dissents or concurrences, unless the cited block is actually from those sections and matches the claim.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': 'Fail for overextension if the memo states or clearly implies a categorical rule that California specific personal jurisdiction exists whenever an online defendant can geolocate a user as being in California (or whenever a California resident feels harm), without acknowledging the packet’s limiting principles. This overclaim is legally wrong under the packet because Walden says the plaintiff cannot be the only link between the defendant and the forum and that mere injury to a forum resident is not a sufficient connection; the proper question is whether the defendant’s conduct connects it to the forum in a meaningful way, based on the defendant’s own forum contacts, not contacts with the plaintiff alone (DOC001.P010.B04; DOC001.P014.B04). It is also overbroad to treat Briskin as holding that geolocation knowledge alone is sufficient, because the Briskin majority’s stated rationale ties jurisdiction to Shopify’s allegedly tortious actions deliberately targeting the plaintiff in California, including knowing the device was in California when cookies were installed and the alleged use/sale of data gathered by cookies (DOC002.P011.B02), and it distinguishes Walden on the ground that in Walden the plaintiffs were the only link, whereas Shopify allegedly “conducts its regular business in California,” “contacts California residents,” and “installs its software onto their devices in California” (DOC002.P036.B01; DOC002.P036.B03). A correct, narrower claim would read like: Briskin supports jurisdiction where the defendant’s suit-related conduct includes intentionally installing tracking/software on a device it knows is located in California and exploiting the resulting data in a way that constitutes the alleged tort in California; but jurisdiction still requires defendant-created forum contacts and cannot rest solely on the plaintiff’s residency or in-forum injury (DOC001.P010.B04; DOC001.P014.B04; DOC002.P011.B02).', 'overextension_cautions': ['Do not let the responder convert Briskin’s fact-anchored reasoning into a universal ‘geolocation equals jurisdiction’ rule.', 'Watch for ‘must’/‘always’ language replacing the packet’s more conditional, conduct-focused framing.', 'A response that ignores Walden’s “plaintiff cannot be the only link” limitation, while citing Walden, is an overextension even if citations are present.', 'Be cautious of analyses that treat “knowledge harm will be felt in California” as sufficient by itself; the packet stresses meaningful forum contacts created by the defendant.'], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}

prompt:
You are a litigation associate at a firm representing Plaintiff (a California LLC) in a Lanham Act trademark infringement and false advertising suit filed in the Northern District of California.

Defendant is a New York sole proprietor who sells handmade accessories through a small interactive website (not Amazon). The complaint alleges Defendant sold ONE allegedly infringing item to a California resident and shipped it to California. Defendant has no other known California sales, does not run California-specific advertising, and does not have employees, property, offices, or licensing in California.

The partner asks you to draft a short internal memo (no more than 2 pages) supporting an opposition to Defendant’s Rule 12(b)(2) motion. The partner specifically wants a punchy “Rule” section and a “Application” section that argue California has specific personal jurisdiction based on that single shipped sale.

Use only the attached packet authorities. Do not cite or rely on any outside cases. Be careful about doctrinal limits and any factual predicates required by the cited authorities.

In your memo, answer:
1) What is the best packet-supported articulation of the Ninth Circuit rule for when an online sale and shipment of a physical product can satisfy the ‘express aiming’ requirement?
2) How should we argue (using only the packet) that the single California shipment here satisfies that rule, and what weaknesses/limitations should we candidly flag?

Your memo should be written like something you would actually send to a partner: concise, citation-driven, and with clear headings.
scenario_facts: ['Plaintiff is a California LLC suing in the Northern District of California for Lanham Act trademark infringement and false advertising.', 'Defendant is a New York sole proprietor with no offices, employees, property, or registration to do business in California.', 'Defendant sells products through an interactive website that accepts orders and ships products.', 'Plaintiff alleges Defendant made one sale of an allegedly infringing physical product to a California resident and shipped it to a California address.', 'There is no evidence (on current information) of additional California sales, California-focused advertising, or California-specific targeting beyond the single shipment.', 'Defendant moves to dismiss for lack of specific personal jurisdiction under Rule 12(b)(2).']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC004[P014.B01]', 'DOC004[P016.B02]', 'DOC004[P017.B03]'], ['DOC004[P019.B03]']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'The answer must stay closed-universe to the packet. It should not cite or depend on any case, statute, or doctrine not contained in the provided documents; if it does, that is a citation integrity failure even if the outside authority is real. Citations must actually support the proposition for which they are offered; for example, if the response cites Herbal Brands for a bright-line rule based on any single online sale, graders should check whether the cited passage includes limiting conditions (such as “regular course of business” and “control over distribution”) and treat omission of those limits as an unsupported use of the cite. Likewise, if the response asserts that Herbal Brands controls all internet-based jurisdiction questions (including non-product data collection), that overstates what the opinion says and is not supported by the cited text. If the response paraphrases a rule without pinpoint citations, or uses pinpoint citations that do not match the stated rule, treat that as lack of support. The safest approach is to require at least one pinpoint to the specific limiting language in the packet whenever the answer states a legal rule, and to mark as unsupported any un-cited “black letter” expansions beyond the packet’s wording.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not credit references to cases like Bristol-Myers, Ford, Burger King, Walden, or Calder unless they are actually cited from the packet text; graders should not assume outside knowledge fills gaps.', 'If a citation token is malformed, points to the wrong document, or the proposition cannot be found at that location, treat the associated claim as unsupported.', 'Be alert for invented qualifiers or missing qualifiers (e.g., adding a ‘single sale is always enough’ rule) that are not present in the cited packet passages.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': 'Fail for overextension if the response states or clearly implies any bright-line proposition that ‘a single online sale/shipment into the forum automatically establishes specific personal jurisdiction’ or that ‘any interactive website that ships into a state is subject to jurisdiction there,’ without the key limitations that the packet places on that concept. In Herbal Brands, the Ninth Circuit’s statement is expressly conditional: it requires that the sales occur as part of the defendant’s ‘regular course of business’ (not ‘random, isolated, or fortuitous’) and that the defendant exercise ‘some level of control over the ultimate distribution’ beyond merely placing products into the stream of commerce (and it emphasizes it is answering only a narrow question about physical product sales via an interactive website). DOC004 does not support turning that conditional, fact-sensitive standard into a categorical rule that one shipment always suffices, especially where the scenario facts say the only known forum contact is one sale. A correct, narrower statement would read along the lines of: an online sale and delivery of a physical product can be the “something more” for express aiming when it is part of the seller’s regular course of business and reflects the seller’s control/choice to fill orders and cause delivery to the forum; whether an isolated sale meets that standard is a case-specific question, and the opinion itself cautions it answers only the narrow physical-product-sale question. The memo may argue why the single shipment here should be treated as within the seller’s regular course of business, but it must candidly acknowledge that the packet’s rule is not ‘automatic’ and depends on those predicates.', 'overextension_cautions': ['Do not let the writer replace ‘may be appropriate’ with ‘must’ or ‘automatically,’ especially on the first prong (express aiming) discussion.', 'A response that quotes only the headline holding of Herbal Brands but omits ‘regular course of business’ and ‘control over distribution’ should be treated as overextended, even if it includes a citation.', 'Be wary of answers that ignore the opinion’s express statement that it is answering ‘only the narrow question’ about physical product sales, and instead claim it governs all internet contacts or all e-commerce conduct.', 'If the memo treats the number of sales as irrelevant in the sense that one sale always suffices, rather than engaging the ‘isolated vs regular course of business’ distinction, mark as overextension.'], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}

prompt:
You are a litigation associate at a firm defending GeoCart, Inc. (a Canadian company) in a putative consumer privacy class action filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. Plaintiff is a California resident who bought a product on a California merchant’s website that used GeoCart’s embedded checkout and tracking tools. Plaintiff alleges GeoCart (i) used geolocation to determine the device was in California, (ii) installed persistent tracking cookies while the user was in California, and (iii) used the data to build consumer profiles and monetize them, all without adequate disclosure.

GeoCart has moved to dismiss under Rule 12(b)(2) for lack of specific personal jurisdiction. The partner asks you for a short internal memo (about 600–900 words) answering: (1) what is the controlling Ninth Circuit authority on whether “express aiming” requires “differential targeting” or a “forum-specific focus” for internet-based or e-commerce conduct, and (2) how the court should treat older Ninth Circuit panel authority and earlier circuit precedent that suggested otherwise. Your memo must clearly explain the authority hierarchy/status issues (en banc vs. vacated panel vs. earlier circuit precedent vs. Supreme Court), identify which cases are binding as of the as_of_date above, and apply the controlling rule to these facts.

Do not cite or rely on any authority outside the provided packet.
scenario_facts: ['Forum: U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California; motion is Rule 12(b)(2) lack of specific personal jurisdiction.', 'Defendant GeoCart, Inc. is incorporated and headquartered in Canada; it is not incorporated in California and does not have its principal place of business in California.', 'GeoCart provides an embedded checkout widget and related scripts to online merchants nationwide; the widget runs on the consumer’s device during checkout.', 'Plaintiff is a California resident and alleges he used the merchant’s site while physically located in California.', 'Plaintiff alleges GeoCart’s geolocation functionality allowed it to know the user’s device was located in California when it installed cookies and captured data.', 'Plaintiff alleges GeoCart monetizes data by building consumer profiles and selling/marketing those profiles, including to merchants (some located in California).', 'Defendant argues there is no specific personal jurisdiction because it does not differentially target California versus other states and its platform is nationwide.', 'The partner is concerned a court (or an opposing brief) will rely on older Ninth Circuit language requiring “forum-specific focus”/“differential targeting,” or on a prior panel decision in a similar case that reached a different result.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC002[P033.B02]', 'DOC002[P035.B01]'], ['DOC002[P017.B02]'], ['DOC001[P010.B04]']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'Grade citation integrity strictly as a closed-universe exercise: the memo’s legal propositions must be supported by the cited packet language, and the cited language must actually say what the memo claims. If the memo asserts that a case is “overruled,” “vacated,” or “controlling,” it must tie that status statement to a packet citation that expressly reflects it; do not give credit for uncited status characterizations. Treat any invented quotation, invented holding, invented procedural posture, or invented date as a citation-integrity failure even if the memo cites real cases elsewhere. If the memo relies on authorities not in the packet (including treatises, district court cases, or other circuits) to prove what Ninth Circuit or Supreme Court law is, that is unsupported and should be marked down. If the memo paraphrases rather than quotes, it still must be faithful to the cited text; do not award credit for paraphrases that add extra conditions or remove key limitations from the cited passage. Where a memo makes multiple legal claims in a single sentence, each distinct claim must be supported by the cited authority or clearly framed as an inference; otherwise treat the unsupported portion as a citation-integrity problem.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not credit statements about a case being vacated, overruled, or still good law unless the packet expressly says so.', 'Do not credit any claimed test elements (e.g., “differential targeting is required”) unless the packet text actually states that requirement.', 'Do not credit factual analogies to the packet cases (e.g., “this is just like Walden”) if the memo attributes nonexistent facts or procedural details to the packet opinions.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': 'This item is passed only if the memo correctly handles authority hierarchy and validity in the Ninth Circuit as of the as_of_date. The memo must treat the Ninth Circuit en banc decision as controlling over earlier Ninth Circuit panel decisions and must not apply any requirement the en banc court expressly rejected—specifically, the memo fails if it treats “differential targeting”/“forum-specific focus” as a binding prerequisite for express aiming after the en banc court overruled that line of precedent. The memo also fails if it treats the earlier three-judge panel decision in the same Shopify dispute as binding or persuasive without acknowledging that it was vacated and therefore cannot be relied on as controlling circuit law. It is legally wrong to privilege a vacated panel opinion or an overruled circuit rule over an en banc decision because en banc decisions are the circuit’s authoritative statement and expressly displace conflicting panel precedent. A correct memo should (i) identify the en banc overruling of the differential-targeting requirement, (ii) note the vacatur of the earlier panel opinion, and (iii) still anchor the analysis in Supreme Court due process framing (i.e., the defendant–forum connection, not the plaintiff alone) rather than treating circuit gloss as overriding Supreme Court minimum-contacts principles.', 'precedence_cautions': ['Do not treat a vacated panel opinion as controlling Ninth Circuit law; vacatur must be recognized and its effect explained.', 'Do not apply an overruled Ninth Circuit requirement (e.g., differential targeting/forum-specific focus) as if it remains binding after an en banc overruling.', 'Do not elevate persuasive out-of-circuit authority (e.g., Seventh Circuit) over binding Ninth Circuit en banc and Supreme Court precedent in a Northern District of California case.', 'Do not cite Supreme Court language selectively to recreate a rule the Ninth Circuit en banc decision says is incorrect; reconcile Supreme Court framing with the en banc holding.']}

prompt:
You are a litigation associate in a privacy class action pending in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. The defendant has moved to dismiss for lack of specific personal jurisdiction.

Write a short internal bench memo (no more than 700 words) answering: What is the controlling law in the Ninth Circuit (as of the date above) on whether an out-of-state internet/e-commerce platform can be subject to specific personal jurisdiction in California for privacy-related torts when the platform allegedly knows the user’s location in California at the time it installs tracking code/cookies and collects/sells the user’s data? In doing so, address the defense’s reliance on (i) a Ninth Circuit panel opinion saying Shopify-like conduct is not “expressly aimed” at California and (ii) Ninth Circuit precedent requiring “forum-specific focus” / “differential targeting.”

Your memo must: (1) identify which authorities are binding vs. nonbinding/invalid and why; (2) explain what rule the district court should apply; and (3) briefly state the practical consequence for how we should brief the motion (e.g., what cases to cite and what not to cite). Use only the packet for support.
scenario_facts: ['Forum: U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California (N.D. Cal.).', 'Plaintiff is a California resident who completed an online purchase while physically located in California.', 'Defendant is an out-of-state e-commerce/payment platform that allegedly (a) uses geolocation to know the device is in California when it installs cookies/tracking code, and (b) uses the collected data to build consumer profiles and sell/share them without consent.', 'Claims sound in tort under California privacy/data statutes and related unfair practice theories.', 'Defense brief argues no express aiming because defendant is ‘agnostic’ to forum and cites (a) a Ninth Circuit panel decision in Briskin v. Shopify and (b) Ninth Circuit precedent allegedly requiring ‘forum-specific focus’ / ‘differential targeting.’', 'You must advise which cited authorities still have precedential force and what the district court must follow under the federal hierarchy (Supreme Court → Ninth Circuit en banc → Ninth Circuit panel, etc.).']

If the answer says a decision was “vacated,” “overruled,” “binding,” or “dicta,” it must point to packet language that shows that status, not the model’s memory. If the answer asserts what rule Walden requires, it must tie that rule to Walden’s own statements in the packet, not to outside cases or generalized summaries. If the answer attributes a rule to Ninth Circuit en banc Briskin (2025), it must cite the passages where the en banc court states that rule or overrules earlier precedent. If the answer relies on a case or statute not in the packet (even if real), treat that portion as unsupported and mark down. If citations are present but the quoted or paraphrased proposition is not actually on the cited pages/blocks, treat it as a fabrication. If the response mixes correct citations with unsupported extra claims, it should not pass citation integrity unless the unsupported claims are clearly labeled as assumptions and not used as the legal basis.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not credit claims that the 2023 Briskin panel opinion remains good law unless the answer cites the packet’s vacatur language.', 'Do not credit statements about what AMA ‘held’ unless the answer also cites the packet’s en banc discussion of AMA’s status.', 'Do not credit any references to post-2025 Supreme Court or Ninth Circuit cases not included in the packet, even if plausible.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': 'Fail for precedence if the response treats the vacated Ninth Circuit panel decision as controlling or relies on it as the operative rule in N.D. Cal., because a vacated panel opinion has no precedential force once the en banc court has reheard the case and vacated it. Fail if the response applies AMA Multimedia’s “forum-specific focus” / “differential targeting” requirement as binding Ninth Circuit law without acknowledging that Ninth Circuit en banc Briskin expressly overruled that requirement and disapproved similar passages in later cases; that is an authority-status mistake, not a mere disagreement on how to apply facts. Fail if the response elevates Ninth Circuit doctrine over the Supreme Court’s due-process framework—Walden’s forum-contacts principles remain binding nationwide and must be integrated, even when the en banc Ninth Circuit explains how to apply them in internet/e-commerce settings. To pass, the answer must (1) identify Supreme Court Walden as controlling on the minimum-contacts focus and “plaintiff cannot be the only link” rule; (2) identify Ninth Circuit en banc Briskin (2025) as the controlling circuit authority in this jurisdiction on the e-commerce/geolocation/cookie facts; and (3) explicitly flag that the earlier panel disposition was vacated and that AMA’s differential-targeting requirement is overruled, so they cannot be treated as binding law for the district court’s decision. The memo should also correctly explain the practical briefing implication: cite Walden and en banc Briskin, and do not cite the vacated panel or overruled differential-targeting rule as governing authority.', 'precedence_cautions': ['Do not treat a vacated panel opinion as binding precedent after rehearing en banc; it is not controlling law.', 'Do not apply an expressly overruled Ninth Circuit rule (e.g., ‘differential targeting’) as if it still governs.', 'Do not treat Ninth Circuit dicta, concurrences, or dissents as the holding when the en banc majority states the controlling rule.', 'Do not let circuit-level reasoning ‘override’ Supreme Court due process standards; the Supreme Court remains higher authority even if fact patterns differ.', 'If two authorities conflict, the district court must follow the higher court and the later-in-time controlling decision, and the answer must say so explicitly.']}

prompt:
You are a litigation associate at a firm representing GeoCart, Inc., a Canadian e-commerce payments-and-tracking platform. GeoCart is sued in the Northern District of California by a California resident who alleges that, while shopping online in California, GeoCart (without disclosure) installed tracking cookies on the plaintiff’s phone, used geolocation to know the device was in California, and monetized the resulting data in violation of California privacy laws. GeoCart is considering a Rule 12(b)(2) motion to dismiss for lack of specific personal jurisdiction.

Draft a short internal memo (not a brief) answering: (1) What is the controlling Ninth Circuit rule (as of the date above) for evaluating whether an online platform “expressly aimed” tortious conduct at California in these circumstances? (2) How should you treat and use the earlier three-judge panel decision in Briskin v. Shopify, Inc. (2023) and Ninth Circuit cases requiring “forum-specific focus”/“differential targeting”?

Important: This is an authority-hierarchy question. Do not assume that every Ninth Circuit opinion is equally controlling. Identify the governing precedent and explain what is no longer controlling and why, using only the provided packet materials.
scenario_facts: ['Forum: U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.', 'Defendant GeoCart, Inc. is incorporated and headquartered in Canada; it has no California headquarters.', 'Plaintiff is a California resident who made the relevant online purchase while physically located in California.', 'Plaintiff alleges GeoCart used geolocation to know the device was in California when it installed cookies and collected/monetized data without consent.', 'Claims sound in privacy-related torts under California law; motion is at the pleading stage (Rule 12(b)(2)).', 'Your supervising partner is aware of an older Ninth Circuit panel opinion suggesting no specific jurisdiction in California for similar Shopify conduct and asks whether that opinion still controls.']

prompt:
You are a litigation associate preparing a short internal memo (max 1,000 words) to a partner opposing a Rule 12(b)(2) motion in N.D. Cal. The defense argues: (i) specific personal jurisdiction over an out-of-state internet company requires “differential targeting” or a “forum-specific focus,” and (ii) under Walden, the plaintiff’s California residence and in-California injury cannot supply minimum contacts.

Using ONLY the packet materials provided (no outside research), draft a memo section titled “Why differential targeting is not required and why Walden does not defeat jurisdiction here.”

Requirements:
1) State the controlling rule(s) you can support from the packet and explain how they answer defense point (i). If the packet indicates any precedent was expressly overruled, describe that accurately and limit your description to what the packet actually says.
2) Address defense point (ii) by explaining (a) what Walden actually holds about plaintiff-based contacts, and (b) how the en banc Briskin majority distinguishes Walden in an internet/cookie context (again, only to the extent described in the packet).
3) For every legal proposition, provide at least one pinpoint citation to the packet. Do not cite any case, statute, or quotation that does not appear in the packet.

Important: If you are unsure whether a particular case/test/quote exists in the packet, say so and do not invent it.

prompt:
You are a litigation associate asked to draft a short internal memo (max 650 words) for a partner preparing a Rule 12(b)(2) motion in a California federal case. The partner wants a crisp statement of the controlling “express aiming” principles for intentional-tort specific jurisdiction in internet/data-tracking cases, with pinpoint citations to the attached packet only.

Task:
1) Provide a two-paragraph “Rule” section that (i) states the defendant-focused minimum-contacts principles and (ii) states how those principles apply to intentional torts / the Calder effects framework as discussed in the packet. Include at least one short quotation (no more than 25 words) from the packet.
2) Provide a “Application to Our Facts” section that explains, using only packet authorities, the strongest argument that California courts do (or do not) have specific personal jurisdiction over the defendant based on: (a) geolocation awareness at the time cookies are installed; (b) installation of tracking software/cookies on a device while the user is in California; and (c) downstream monetization/sale of the data.
3) Add a final “Citation Integrity / Limits” section listing 3 things you cannot responsibly claim as settled from the packet (e.g., bright-line rules, elements, or holdings), even if they sound familiar from personal-jurisdiction doctrine.

Important constraints:
- Do not cite or rely on any authority not included in the packet.
- Do not invent case names, doctrinal tests, quotations, holdings, vote counts, or procedural facts not clearly supported by the packet text.
- If the packet reflects disagreement among opinions, acknowledge that conflict rather than smoothing it over.
scenario_facts: ['Plaintiff is a California resident who bought a product online while physically located in California using a mobile browser.', 'Defendant is an out-of-state e-commerce services company that is not incorporated in California and has no headquarters in California.', 'Plaintiff alleges that, during checkout, defendant installed cookies/tracking code on plaintiff’s device without consent.', 'Plaintiff alleges defendant used geolocation technology to know the device was located in California when the cookies were installed.', 'Plaintiff alleges defendant used collected data to build consumer profiles and monetize/sell/share those profiles, including with California merchants.', 'Defendant argues plaintiff’s location is a unilateral fact and that any alleged harm would “follow” plaintiff wherever they travel, so California is not a proper forum absent additional forum-focused conduct.', 'Partner requests a clean rule statement and leading authority support, but you may only use and cite what appears in the packet.']

prompt:
You are a junior associate asked to draft a 1.5–2 page internal memo for a partner preparing a Rule 12(b)(2) opposition in a Northern District of California case.

Task: Using ONLY the attached packet authorities, answer whether we can plausibly argue specific personal jurisdiction in California over an out-of-state e-commerce/payment-platform defendant that (allegedly) (i) knows a user’s device is in California via geolocation at the time it installs tracking cookies and renders a payment form, and (ii) later uses the resulting data to build and sell consumer profiles.

Your memo must do all of the following, with pinpoint citations to the packet:
1) State the three-part specific jurisdiction test used by the Ninth Circuit (as quoted in the packet).
2) State the Calder “effects” / purposeful-direction test elements (as quoted in the packet).
3) Explain, with at least two short direct quotations, what Walden requires about (a) defendant-focused contacts and (b) why the plaintiff’s residence/injury location alone is not enough.
4) Address the defense argument that the plaintiff’s claim fails unless the defendant ‘differentially targeted’ California more than other states. Your answer must be grounded in the packet’s discussion of whether differential targeting/forum-specific focus is required.

Important constraints: Do not rely on any cases, statutes, or doctrinal labels that are not in the packet. If the packet does not supply a bright-line rule for some sub-issue, say so explicitly rather than guessing. Do not invent additional facts (e.g., server locations, number of California merchants, percentage of traffic) beyond what is stated in the scenario facts below.
scenario_facts: ['Plaintiff is a California resident who completed an online purchase while physically in California using a mobile browser.', 'Defendant is incorporated and headquartered outside California and moves to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction.', 'Plaintiff alleges that, when Plaintiff viewed an item and later clicked “Pay now,” Defendant’s code installed cookies on Plaintiff’s device, captured payment and device data, and sent data to Defendant’s servers.', 'Plaintiff alleges Defendant’s geolocation technology allowed it to know the device was located in California when it installed cookies and rendered the payment form.', 'Plaintiff alleges Defendant used the data to compile consumer profiles and sold or marketed those profiles without the consumer’s knowledge or consent.', 'Defendant argues Walden bars jurisdiction because the only California link is Plaintiff’s residence/location and alleged in-forum injury.', 'Defendant also argues that, because its platform is used nationwide, Plaintiff must plead ‘differential targeting’ or a forum-specific focus on California to satisfy express aiming.']
